newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia raises Oct T-bill mkt limit for foreigners.
newsitem.headline: Russia raises Oct T-bill mkt limit for foreigners.

text.p: Russia's central bank has raised the limit for non-residents on the government securities market for October to $1.5 billion from $1.0 billion, the bank's first deputy chairman Sergei Aleksashenko told Reuters on Tuesday.
The central bank has not yet set a November limit, he said.

The authorities control the amount which non-residents can invest in the government securities market by limiting the total amount of foreign currency which Russian banks can buy from non-residents investing in the market.
Inflows in this way had already reached $850-900 million by October 15, compared with the limit for the month of $1 billion, central bank officials said.
Investment in August had totalled $350-$400 million against a limit of $700 million, and in September totalled $850 million against a limit of $1 billion.

Foreign investment in the market rose substantially in early October after the central bank announced it was reducing the guaranteed dollar yield to non-residents to 16 percent from 19 percent as of October 16.
Since August non-residents have been able to invest in Russian GKO T-bills and OFZ government bonds by opening special "S" rouble accounts with designated Russian banks.
They can use these accounts to buy government securities at auction or buy and sell them in the secondary market.
There is no limit on the amount which can be repatriated from these accounts, and no limit on the amount of each individual issue which foreigners can buy.
But non-residents have to buy foreign currency from these accounts using forward transactions or options with a term of at least three months.

The central bank regulates the guaranteed dollar yield available to non-residents buying securities at auction and holding them to maturity by requiring Russian banks to offset a proportion of these forward deals with the central bank, at rates determined by the central bank.

The guaranteed yield of 16 percent in dollar terms is still one of the highest available for fixed-income instruments, but Russian bankers say non-residents can raise their return by playing the secondary market aggressively.
